pageContext.description:
This portrait of Elector Joachim II (German, 1505-1571) depicts the ruler as heir apparent, six years before he assumed the electoral dignity. It is the companion to Cranach's portrait of Joachim's wife, Magdalena of Saxony (1507-1534), now at the Art Institute of Chicago. Joachim's pearl-decorated doublet displays two repeated motifs: the head of a jester and the letter M. Each M is topped with a heart and crown, probably in playful reference to Magdalena as the queen of Joachim's heart. The jesters may allude to the widespread notion that folly accompanies love. 
[http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/102550.html?mulR=15983|5](accessed 21.03.2013)

metadata.title: Portrait of Joachim II, Elector of Brandenburg

pageContext.provenance:
- Gustav Fincke (d. 1865), Bamberg, until d. 1865 (with the companion portrait, now Art Institute of Chicago, with which it remained until separated during the Schönlank sale in 1896)
- his estate sale, Bamberg, September 11 and following, 1865, no. [?]; probably purchased by Carl Christian Buchner (1817-1886), Bamberg, until d. 1886 [1]
- his estate sale, Rudolph Lepke, Berlin, June 3-13, 1891, no. 830 (illus.) (bought in?) [2]
- his daughter, Lilli Ament (b. 1851), Bamberg, until 1894; her sale, Rudolf Bangel, Frankfurt, April 9, 1894, no. 108. Alexis Schönlank, Berlin until 1896
- his sale, Kunsthaus Lempertz, Cologne, April 28-29, 1896, no. 34
- purchased by Knoedler & Co., New York [3]
- John G. Johnson (1841-1917), Philadelphia, by 1914, until d. 1917 [4]
- bequest to City of Philadelphia, 1917.

[1] See Theodor Frimmel, Kleine Galeriestudien (Bamberg, 1891), p. 94. 
[2] Note that the illustration in the illustrated version of the sale catalogue is mis-captioned as no. 815.
[3] Note by Abraham Bredius on p. 14 of his copy of the Schönlank sale catalogue (RKD, The Hague).
[4] W[ilhelm]. R[einhold]. Valentiner, Catalogue of a Collection of Paintings and Some Art Objects, vol. 3: German, French, Spanish and English Paintings and Art Objects, Modern Paintings (Philadelphia: John G. Johnson, 1914), p. 13, no. 739, illus. p. 242.
[Philadelphia Museum of Art, revised 2015]

secondaryReferences.remark: Bildträger aus dem selben Baum gefertigt #Wood for support from the same tree

Artist's insignia on the left, above the sitter's shoulder: winged serpent and dated '1529'
[Philadelphia Museum of Art, revised 2015]
